random_events.text: A gentle breeze picks up, carrying with it the scent of wild roses and the distant sound of cricket on the village green.
The weather takes a turn for the dramatic. It's now raining upwards.
A passing narrowboat has stopped to offer you tea and biscuits. The captain appears to be a badger.
Your sandwich has achieved sentience and is now critiquing your casting technique.
The local wildlife has formed a brass band and is playing 'Jerusalem' rather enthusiastically.
A group of morris dancers has appeared from nowhere and insists on performing around your fishing spot.
The river has developed a strong Yorkshire accent and keeps offering unsolicited advice about proper fishing technique.
A family of swans has appointed itself as your personal angling critique committee. Their reviews are harsh but fair.
The local church bells begin playing 'God Save the King' in what can only be described as interpretive campanology.
A distinguished gentleman in Victorian dress tips his hat and compliments your 'modern angling apparatus' before vanishing into thin air.
The fish have organized a protest march. Their demands include better fly patterns and more realistic casting techniques.
A hot air balloon drifts overhead, its passengers shouting encouragement and fishing advice in what sounds like ancient Latin.
The local postman arrives by punt to deliver what appears to be a strongly worded letter from the Angling Standards Authority.
A group of academic-looking ducks has gathered to observe your technique. One appears to be taking notes.
The village cricket team has declared a tea break and wandered over to offer commentary on your casting form.
A mysterious fog rolls in, carrying with it the faint sound of Gregorian chanting and the smell of fish and chips.
The local wildlife has formed a queue behind you, apparently waiting their turn to try fishing.
A passing rambler stops to inform you that you're fishing in a location that doesn't technically exist on any map.
The river suddenly develops perfect mirror-like clarity, revealing that the fish below are playing cards and ignoring your fly entirely.
A small delegation of garden gnomes has appeared to observe your angling technique. Their expressions suggest professional interest.

check_time.text: Your watch indicates it's teatime, which explains everything.
According to your timepiece, it's currently next Thursday.
Time appears to have stopped, possibly out of embarrassment.
Your pocket watch suggests it's precisely the moment when fish traditionally ignore all human endeavors.
The time is exactly 'too early for success, too late for excuses.'
Your watch indicates that somewhere in the world, someone is probably catching fish. Just not here.
According to your calculations, you've been fishing for exactly long enough to question all your life choices.
The time is 'half past disappointment, quarter to resignation.'
Your watch cheerfully announces that it's 'the perfect time for philosophical reflection on the nature of angling failure.'

check_weather.text: The weather is absolutely perfect for fishing, which is precisely why nothing will go according to plan.
Light drizzle is beginning, which in Hampshire means you have approximately 30 seconds before the apocalypse.
The sun is shining brilliantly, causing the fish to don tiny sunglasses and refuse to cooperate.
A gentle mist is rising from the water, carrying with it the dreams of frustrated anglers.
The weather has achieved consciousness and is now taking requests.
The meteorological conditions suggest that somewhere, in a parallel universe, you're probably catching fish.
The weather is behaving with typical British unpredictability - simultaneously perfect and completely wrong for fishing.
The barometric pressure indicates 'optimal conditions for aquatic disappointment.'
The weather forecast called for 'scattered showers with a chance of angling success.' The showers arrived on schedule.
The atmospheric conditions are perfect for everything except catching fish, which is unfortunately your primary objective.
The weather appears to be collaborating with the fish in a conspiracy against angling success.

spring.text: The mayflies begin their ancient dance above the water, completely ignoring your carefully selected imitation.
Spring lambs in the adjacent field pause their frolicking to observe your angling technique with what appears to be professional concern.
The first swallows of spring arrive and immediately begin offering aerial commentary on your casting form.

summer.text: The summer heat creates perfect hatching conditions for every insect except the one your fly is supposed to represent.
A family of picnickers sets up nearby and begins a running commentary on your fishing technique while enjoying their sandwiches.
The summer evening light creates perfect conditions for photography, which several tourists take advantage of, using you as an unwitting subject.

autumn.text: Autumn leaves drift down from the trees, each one landing precisely where your fly was supposed to go.
The changing seasons have apparently confused the fish, who are now behaving according to a completely different calendar.
A red deer appears on the opposite bank and watches your angling efforts with what can only be described as sympathetic understanding.

winter.text: The winter air is crisp and clear, providing perfect visibility for observing the complete absence of fish.
A robin lands nearby and begins what appears to be a motivational speech about persistence in the face of adversity.
The bare winter trees provide an unobstructed view of your casting failures for miles around.

river.text: The river current carries away your hopes and dreams along with several expensive flies.
An otter surfaces nearby, examines your technique, and dives again with what appears to be disappointment.
The river whispers ancient secrets about fish behavior, but unfortunately speaks in a dialect you don't understand.

reservoir.text: A sailing boat passes by, its crew offering helpful suggestions about your angling technique through a megaphone.
The reservoir's depth finder reveals that all the fish are currently holding a meeting at the bottom, discussing your fishing strategy.
A cormorant surfaces with a fish in its beak, demonstrating the proper technique with what appears to be deliberate smugness.
